title: Eczema Area and Severity Index (EASI)
description: Stratifies eczema severity by assessing area involvement and severity signs across four body regions (head/neck, upper extremities, trunk, lower extremities) with validated clinical scoring.

parameters.name: age_category
parameters.description: Patient age category for regional multiplier calculation

result.name: easi_score
result.description: EASI total score ranging from 0 to 72 points

ranges.interpretation: Clear skin with no signs of atopic dermatitis. Continue maintenance skincare routine and environmental management.
Almost clear atopic dermatitis with minimal residual signs. Continue current treatment and monitor for improvement or relapse.
Mild atopic dermatitis. First-line treatment with topical moisturizers, low-potency topical corticosteroids, and trigger avoidance.
Moderate atopic dermatitis. Consider medium-potency topical corticosteroids, topical calcineurin inhibitors, or systemic therapy if topical treatments inadequate.
Severe atopic dermatitis. High-potency topical corticosteroids, topical calcineurin inhibitors, systemic immunosuppressants, or biologic therapy may be indicated.
Very severe atopic dermatitis requiring aggressive treatment. Consider systemic immunosuppressants, biologic therapy, or referral to dermatology specialist for comprehensive management.

references: Hanifin JM, Thurston M, Omoto M, Cherill R, Tofte SJ, Graeber M. The eczema area and severity index (EASI): assessment of reliability in atopic dermatitis. EASI Evaluator Group. Exp Dermatol. 2001;10(1):11-8. doi: 10.1034/j.1600-0625.2001.100102.x.

Schmitt J, Langan S, Deckert S, Svensson A, von Kobyletzki L, Thomas K, et al. Assessment of clinical signs of atopic dermatitis: a systematic review and recommendation. J Allergy Clin Immunol. 2013;132(6):1337-47. doi: 10.1016/j.jaci.2013.07.008.

Barbarot S, Auziere S, Gadkari A, Girolomoni G, Puig L, Simpson EL, et al. Epidemiology of atopic dermatitis in adults: Results from an international survey. Allergy. 2018;73(6):1284-1293. doi: 10.1111/all.13401.
Silverberg JI, Paller AS, Fishbein AB, Kaplan DH, Simpson EL. Eczema prevalence, severity and impact in the United States. Dermatitis. 2019;30(1):66-72. doi: 10.1097/DER.0000000000000408.
formula: EASI = 0.1 × (erythema + edema + excoriation + lichenification) × area_score × head_neck_multiplier + 0.2 × (erythema + edema + excoriation + lichenification) × area_score × upper_extremities_multiplier + 0.3 × (erythema + edema + excoriation + lichenification) × area_score × trunk_multiplier + 0.4 × (erythema + edema + excoriation + lichenification) × area_score × lower_extremities_multiplier. Regional multipliers: Head/neck = 0.1 (adults), 0.2 (children 0-7); Upper extremities = 0.2; Trunk = 0.3; Lower extremities = 0.4.
notes: The EASI is the most validated and widely used assessment tool for atopic dermatitis severity.
Assessment requires approximately 6 minutes when performed by a trained investigator.
Four severity signs assessed: erythema (redness), edema/papulation (swelling/bumps), excoriation (scratching marks), lichenification (thickening)
Regional multipliers reflect relative contribution to total body surface area.
Head/neck multiplier: 0.1 for adults (>8 years), 0.2 for children (0-7 years)
Upper extremities multiplier: 0.2 for all ages
Trunk multiplier: 0.3 for all ages (includes axilla and groin)
Lower extremities multiplier: 0.4 for all ages (includes feet and buttocks)
Total score ranges from 0 to 72 points.
Common pitfall: underestimating erythema severity in patients with darker skin pigmentation.
EASI should be completed independently of previous assessments - it is a static tool.
Does not include assessment of dryness or scaling.
Severity strata validated with substantial inter-rater agreement (κ = 0.75).
Clinical correlation: Higher EASI scores associated with increased pruritus, sleep disturbance, and quality of life impairment.
Recommended for clinical trials and research as primary efficacy endpoint.
